title: What are the most important things you learned from your favorite philosophy course? - Quora

response.answer_text: I college, a required course was Ethics. I took the only one offered, but it turned out to be a Philosophy class. After taking the class, I learned that there is no objective “right” or “wrong”. It all depends on how you look at it. I still essentially subscribe to the Golden Rule, but I was impressed at how philosophers of days past were able to make the argument that some actions that most would objectively label wrong are, on further examination and thought, just and good. About the only thing I remember clearly from that class is Occam’s Razor: When you have two competing theories that make exactly the same predictions, the simpler one is the better Or, in other words: Where there are two or more ways to explain something, the simpler one must be correct The last one was the way we learned it. So, for example, suppose you wondered, “How did that light turn on in that room?” There are two ways presented that it happened: Through an phenomena not understood, an entity formed a conduit from the power source to the lightbulbSomeone flicked on the light switchWhich is more likely? Therefore, it must be correct.

Don’t do to others what you yourself find distasteful to yourself. ( Hillel) know waht you can change, accept what you can’t and have wisdom to know the difference (desaderia, sp?) all men have necks. All bottles have necks. Therefore all men are bottles.
